text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantino here the Internet's
busiest music nerd and album review time
Lamb of God
resolution these guys are a Virginia
metal band that I actually mentioned in
my most anticipated albums of 2012 list
especially since I haven't gotten the
chance to talk about any of this bands
music and they do have a pretty large
reputation in the metal world resolution
is the sixth full-length studio album
these guys have pulled together as Lamb
of God and it pumps out the kind of grew
grew grew grew grooves riffs and
breakdowns that you would usually hear
on the groove metal record a metalcore
record and what exactly do those genres
mean well both of them are heavily
indebted to thrash metal of the 80s and
90s in thrash metal the riff is king as
well but in metalcore and groove metal
the rips usually aren't that speedy
they're more mid paced and they become
especially slow if there's a breakdown
involved the riffs in this style of
music usually have a lot of punch to
them a lot of shudder just these
continuous start/stop shots of guitar
distortion there's even a spot on track
6 where there's like some
post-production editing on the guitar
riffs make them feel even more sharp
make them feel even more robotic when it
comes to modern metal hitting the
mainstream it's been a lot of Records
like this in this style that have been
signed on to major labels or have gotten
heavy rotation play on metal radio
stations and that's fine I understand
why it's popular I understand why it's
marketable it's music that's created to
just elicit an emotional reaction an
aggressive emotional reaction as fast as
possible not even leaving you time to
think about what you're hearing
aggression is lame of God's greatest
asset on this record on
to their records when it comes to that
emotion these guys are about as instant
as ramen noodles but I think the
popularity of this kind of songwriting
in metal music has kind of changed the
public face of metal a little bit though
there are exceptions like Between the
Buried and Me and converge this style of
music isn't usually big on detail or
variation or songwriting you know not to
be really brutal about it but I think
it's kind of records like this that
reinforce a lot of metal stereotypes
that metal is nothing but just screaming
and just senseless anger and breakdowns
but you know it's it's whatever because
if somebody really wants to believe that
then they're the ones missing out this
LP is an album that kind of fits that
mold though if you guys watch my videos
especially my metal reviews you already
know that I love aggressive music but
the thing is Lamb of God doesn't really
bring much else into the equation there
almost no unique song topics or lyrics
on this record it's actually a lot of
tunes on here about kind of being alone
or being singled out and that's not
necessarily a bad song topic if you put
it in a unique perspective but these
ideas are just painted with a lot of
cliche lyrics about digging your own
grave or bleeding or hands around
someone's throat this album isn't really
huge on on speed or technical ability
not a lot of catchy melodies either and
not a lot of thought-provoking sounds or
production and the vocals don't really
change all that much either track after
track after true
I guess I would have less of an issue
with that if they didn't feel like you
know just kind of generic metal growls
when the vocals do kind of change its to
do a cleanly some chorus or you know
kind of a cheesy narration thing for the
most part on resolution Lamb of God just
focuses on riffs and aggression
with a hint a hint of melody and harmony
hanging somewhere in the air but the
thing is the stuff they focus on with
this LP I don't feel like they do it
particularly well or approach it from a
unique angle the riffs really aren't
that intricate or hard-hitting I mean if
I want an amazing riff there are a
number of Meshuga records I could be
listening to instead for just massive
heaviness and just dizzying rhythms that
sometimes fall into odd time signatures
and as far as aggression goes I just
don't think this album is all that
aggressive it just has this kind of one
level of aggression and it maintains it
throughout the LP and after a while
hearing it at this same level kinda
makes it lose what little flavor adds
and you know it's kind of a shame
because I thought I might be in for
something different with this LP
especially with the introductory track
which was just so slow just so heavy but
after that I just kind of get one song
after another that just feels like I'm
listening to a thrash metal record
that's a bit louder has kind of a modern
shine a modern production to it but has
less melody less songwriting power less
variation between the songs I definitely
give Lamb of God credit for putting
together an LP where they're definitely
using more guitar solos and more guitar
leads than I've heard on previous
efforts there are some spots where the
guitar leads kind of build up into some
nice harmonies even the final track has
string sections playing against the Lamb
of gods distorted guitar chords that
feel that epic feel overall I just think
resolution doesn't throw that many ideas
out there it's just kind of 14 track
headbang fest that doesn't leave you
with much to think about after it's over
and because it doesn't offer a lot of
different ideas it just gets really old
really fast for me maybe if the sound of
the record was better I could see myself
getting into it more you know but the
guitars just don't have a lot of beef to
them you know the kind of sound that I
love to hear on an electric wizard
record or a high on fire record and you
know I do understand that that is not
the style of music that these guys are
playing but still I hate hearing heavy
guitars that really aren't heavy at all
it's just all distortion and no Rumble
it just feels like Lamb of God wants to
leave innovation and experimentation to
all the other bands out there and just
kind of play things by the book and if
that works for them that works for them
but it doesn't work for me because I
just really didn't get much of anything
out of this record I understand why
people like it but it doesn't appeal to
me not at all there are some spots where
I kind of like the riffs and I kind of
like the vocals a little bit but there
was no one song on here that I liked all
the way through kind of feeling a strong
three on this LP but what do you think
about it do you love it do you hate it
why and what do you think I should
review next anthony Fantan Oh Lamb of
God forever
[Music]
